abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, and the institutional development
            impact modest. While the Bank performance is overall, rated
            satisfactory, given a highly satisfactory
            quality-at-entrance, and project supervision assessment, the
            overall Borrower performance can be rated as unsatisfactory,
            due to remaining challenges, such as the need to restore the
            creditworthiness of the utilities, and accelerate
            operational, and commercial improvements of the power
            sector, including privatization. Lessons focus around two
            aspects: 1) the utilization of the Adaptable Program Lending
            (APL) instrument, as a powerful lending instrument in
            dealing with complex reforms, and long execution periods, in
            highly volatile environments. However, and although
            addressed in the Project Appraisal Document risk analysis,
            political factors specifically affected implementation,
            factored by the lending approach which does not lead to a
            situation where conflict may resolve through the application
            of remedies, nor a scaling down of the project objectives:
            seemingly the project was overloaded with ambitious
            objectives, and some covenants were linked to milestones for
            the subsequent operation. It is suggested financial
            covenants need to be addressed, and be given less
            prominence; and, 2) the design, and implementation of a
            reform program, stipulating political support for reforms,
            and ownership are indispensable to sustain a reform process;
            dynamics of reform is essential, as is managing the
            transition of reforms; and, revenue enhancement, does
            demonstrate that state-owned distribution companies can
            reduce losses, contain theft, and trigger governance.
